technical_concept:
A bash script is a file containing a sequence of commands, one per line.

#!/bin/bash — the shebang. First line of every script. Tells the system to use bash.
Variables — store values: NAME="world". Retrieve with $NAME.
read — gets input from the user.
echo — prints output.

Scripts combine everything you've learned — file ops, pipes, text processing — into reusable programs. Save as .sh, make executable with chmod +x, run with ./script.sh.

code_example.code:
#!/bin/bash # Ask the user for a project name echo "Enter project name:" read PROJ_NAME # Create the directory and enter it mkdir $PROJ_NAME cd $PROJ_NAME # Create files touch index.html style.css echo "

Hello from $PROJ_NAME

" > index.html # List the result to show it worked echo "Project $PROJ_NAME created successfully!" ls -F

challenge.task:
Write a bash script that: 1) Creates a directory called 'mysite', 2) Creates 'index.html' and 'style.css' inside it, 3) Writes '

Hello World

' into index.html, 4) Lists the contents of mysite/, 5) Prints 'Done!' when finished. Don't forget the #!/bin/bash shebang!
challenge.hint: Start with #!/bin/bash, then use mkdir, cd into it, create files with touch and echo, list with ls.
challenge.solution:
#!/bin/bash mkdir mysite cd mysite touch index.html style.css echo "

Hello World

" > index.html ls echo "Done!"

dialogue.line: You've mastered individual tools — navigation, files, search, pipes, text processing. Now it's time to combine them into something permanent: a script. A survival manual you can run again and again.

The simplest kind. A bash script is just a text file with commands, one per line. Start with '#!/bin/bash' — that's the shebang. It tells the system: 'this file speaks bash.' After that, every line runs in order, just like typing commands one by one.
Can it remember things? Like a name?
Variables. 'NAME="base camp"' stores a value. '$NAME' retrieves it. 'read ANSWER' waits for your input. You can build interactive tools — a script that asks what you need and builds it for you.
So I could automate setting up camp every time?

Exactly. One script that creates directories, generates files, writes content — your entire camp setup in one command. Every great survivor automates the repetitive tasks. Write a script that builds a small website structure. Prove you can automate survival.
This is it, Ghost. The final lesson. Everything you've learned — navigation, file craft, recon, pipes, xargs, text processing — it all comes together in a script. The masterplan.
A script ties it all together?

A bash script is your operation playbook. It starts with '#!/bin/bash' — the codename header. After that, every line is a step in the plan. They execute in sequence, top to bottom. No manual intervention needed.

'TARGET="vault"' — stores the target name. '$TARGET' recalls it anywhere in the script. 'read INPUT' pauses and waits for your decision. You can make scripts interactive — the plan adapts to conditions on the ground.
So I write the plan once and execute it with one command?

That's the difference between an amateur and a professional. Amateurs type commands one by one. Professionals script the entire operation. Write me a script that sets up a web project — directory, files, content, confirmation. Show me you can plan a clean operation from start to finish.
